definition:
We denote the set
$$D^n(z,r) := \{ w \in {\mathbb{C}}^n \mid \lvert z_k - w_k \rvert < r
\text{ for all } k = 1,\ldots,n \}$$ an [*open polydisc*]{}. We can also
have [*polydiscs*]{} of the form
$$D^1(z_1,r_1) \times \ldots \times D^1(z_n,r_n) .$$ The set
$\partial D^1(z_1,r_1) \times \ldots \times \partial D^1(z_n,r_n)$ is
called the [*distinguished boundary*]{} of the polydisc.

Be careful not to confuse this with the open ball in ${\mathbb{C}}^n$ as
that is defined as
$$B(z,r) := \{ w \in {\mathbb{C}}^n \mid \lvert z - w \rvert < r \} .$$
When $n > 1$ then open balls and open polydiscs are not
biholomorphically equivalent (there is no 1-1 biholomorphic mapping
between the two).

It is common to write $\bar{D}^n(z,r)$ for the closure of the polydisc.
Be careful with this notation however as some texts outside of complex
analysis use $D(x,r)$ and the “disc” to represent a closed ball in two
real dimensions.

Also note that when $n=2$ the is sometimes used.
